author: Augusta Saraiva, Daniel Carvalho
description: When Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and Donald Trump finally talked over their differences Monday, the man at the center of their months-long spat didn’t even merit a mention.
title: Trump Seems to Turn Page on Bolsonaro in ‘Very Good’ Lula Call

author: Josh Sisco, Greg Stohr
description: Alphabet Inc.’s Google lost a US Supreme Court bid to pause major changes to its Google Play app store in an antitrust case filed by Fortnite-maker Epic Games Inc.
title: Supreme Court Denies Google’s Bid to Pause App Store Changes

author: Peter Blumberg
description: President Donald Trump continues to expand troop deployments to US cities, escalating a campaign to assert military power at home with little precedent in US history.
title: How Trump’s Use of Military at Home Tests His Powers

author: Jonnelle Marte
description: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City President Jeff Schmid said officials need to keep pressing against inflation, which has remained stubbornly high.
title: Kansas City Fed President Says Rates Should Lean Against Demand Growth

author: Catherine Lucey
description: President Donald Trump reversed a Biden administration decision blocking the construction of the Ambler Road project in Alaska, in a move he said would open up critical energy and mining projects.
title: Trump Approves Road Project in Alaska, Stake in Trilogy Metals

author: Nathan R Dean
description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Monday, Bloomberg Intelligence senior analyst Nathan Dean gives his insights into what’s been happening and what’s coming up in the nooks and crannies of government and markets.  Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
title: Looking for the Endgame in Washington’s Shutdown Standoff

author: Ignacio Olivera Doll
description: Argentina’s government sold dollars in the foreign-exchange market Monday for a fifth straight session as it tries to stem a slide in the peso, according to two people with direct knowledge of the matter.
title: Argentina Sells Dollars for 5th Day as Treasury Drains Reserves

author: Kamlesh Bhuckory
description: Madagascar President Andry Rajoelina named a military general as the nation’s new prime minister as anti-government protests entered a third week.
title: Madagascar Leader Appoints Military Man as New Prime Minister

author: Maggie Eastland, Edward Ludlow, Caroline Hyde
description: White House AI czar David Sacks defended the Trump administration’s approach to China and said it was essential for the US to dominate artificial intelligence, seeking to rebuff criticism from advocates of a harder line with Beijing.
title: Trump’s AI Czar David Sacks Rebuffs Criticism of China Stance

author: Hadriana Lowenkron
description: President Donald Trump said 25% duties on medium- and heavy-duty trucks would begin Nov. 1, the latest expansion of his tariff regime aimed at protecting domestic industries.
title: Trump Says US Tariffs on Heavy Truck Imports to Begin Nov. 1

author: Ania Nussbaum
description: French President Emmanuel Macron asked his outgoing prime minister, Sebastien Lecornu, to negotiate a way to stabilize the government in the next 48 hours.
title: Macron Asks Lecornu to Negotiate Plan to Bring France Stability

author: Ethan Bronner
description: US President Donald Trump is pressing Israel and Hamas to secure a settlement to the two-year conflict that’s devastated Gaza and destabilized the Middle East, with the warring sides starting mediated negotiations.
title: Trump Pushes for Israel, Hamas Deal as Talks Kick Off in Egypt

author: William Horobin
description: France’s Bruno Le Maire said he has stepped down from the government in order to facilitate the formation of a new cabinet after the resignation of Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu.
title: France’s Le Maire Says New Cabinet Can Be Formed After His Exit

author: Jennifer A Dlouhy
description: The Trump administration is not currently considering a deal that would see it take a stake in Critical Metals Corp., a White House official said Monday, after a report suggesting Washington was considering a position in the rare earths company sent shares skyrocketing.
title: US Government Not Weighing Stake in Critical Metals Corp.

author: Zoe Tillman
description: A federal judge in Maryland denied the Justice Department’s request to pause Kilmar Abrego Garcia’s deportation fight during the government shutdown.
title: DOJ Can’t Delay Abrego Garcia Deportation Case Amid Shutdown

author: Alessandra Migliaccio
description: Giorgia Meloni’s candidate Roberto Occhiuto won a regional election for governor in Italy’s Southern region of Calabria, further boosting support for the Italian Prime minister.
title: Meloni-Backed Candidate Wins Italy Regional Election in Calabria

author: Daryna Krasnolutska, Aliaksandr Kudrytski
description: Ukraine is in talks with key donors to pay for another batch of US weapons even as some allies have been dragging their feet over providing financing, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said.
title: Zelenskiy Implores Allies to Pay for US Weapons Ahead of Winter

author: Erik Hertzberg
description: Prime Minister Mark Carney plans to change when Canada releases major fiscal documents, moving the country’s federal budget to the fall on an ongoing basis.
title: Carney to Push Budgets to Fall in Major Accounting Shift

author: Daniel Carvalho, Augusta Saraiva, Kate Sullivan
description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva asked Donald Trump to remove tariffs on the country’s goods and sanctions on top officials in the first extensive conversation they’ve held since the US leader thrust the South American nation into the center of his global trade war.
title: Lula Asks Trump to End Tariffs as Leaders Agree to Meet Soon

author: Erik Larson, Madlin Mekelburg
description: Illinois sued the Trump administration over its plan to deploy National Guard troops to the Chicago area, setting off a fresh legal battle over the president’s authority to use soldiers to respond to protests over his immigration crackdown.
title: Illinois Sues to Block National Guard Deployment to Chicago Area

author: Georgia Hall
description: New York Republican mayoral candidate Curtis Sliwa vowed to slash $10 billion from the schools budget and trim the Buildings Department to help pay for his proposed tax cuts.
title: NYC Mayoral Candidate Sliwa Targets $10 Billion in School Cuts

author: Greg Stohr
description: The US Supreme Court declined a chance to open social media companies to lawsuits over content recommended by their algorithms, turning away an appeal that accused Meta Platforms Inc.’s Facebook of radicalizing a man who killed nine South Carolina churchgoers.
title: Supreme Court Rejects Bid to Sue Meta Over Church Shooting

author: Greg Stohr
description: The US Supreme Court rejected an appeal by Turkey’s state-owned Halkbank, leaving it facing criminal charges that accuse it of helping Iran evade economic sanctions.
title: Halkbank Rejected by US Supreme Court on Criminal Charges

author: Caitlin Reilly
description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is tapping Social Security Administration Commissioner Frank Bisignano to serve as the chief executive officer of the Internal Revenue Service, a new position at an agency that has undergone multiple leadership shakeups this year.
title: Bessent Taps Bisignano as IRS CEO in Latest Agency Shakeup

author: Patricia Laya
description: Venezuela’s government said it reinforced security around the US embassy in Caracas after uncovering an alleged plot to attack it.
title: Venezuela Says It Foiled Plot to Attack US Embassy in Caracas

author: Paul Richardson
description: Tanzania’s police opened an investigation into the abduction of a former diplomat and senior ruling party official who’s become a fierce critic of President Samia Suluhu Hassan, as the East African nation prepares to hold elections this month.
title: Tanzania Probes Abduction of Government Critic Before Elections

author: Michael Nienaber, Petra Sorge
description: Germany’s ruling coalition confirmed it will extend a tax exemption for new electric vehicles as part of a broader effort to support the nation’s key car industry in the transition to more climate-friendly technologies.
title: German Carmakers Get EV Tax Boost Before Summit With Merz

author: Toru Fujioka
description: A move by the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates this month would likely come too soon after the formation of Sanae Takaichi’s administration and would be better timed in December, according to one of her closest economic advisers.
title: Takaichi Adviser Says October Too Early for BOJ Rate Hike

author: Catherine Lucey, Erik Wasson
description: The White House tightened its pressure on congressional Democrats as a US government shutdown lurched into a second week, saying it would give the holdouts another chance to agree to the spending bill before initiating mass firings of federal workers.
title: White House Raises Pressure on Democrats If Shutdown Vote Fails

author: Zoltan Simon
description: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban said he’d prefer lower interest rates, weighing in on monetary policy as he seeks to kickstart the economy in time for a make-or-break election next year.
title: Hungary’s Orban Advocates for Lower Central Bank Interest Rates

author: Swati Gupta
description: India’s eastern state of Bihar will hold its elections in November, the country’s Election Commission said Monday, in a contest widely seen as a test of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s popularity.
title: India’s Bihar Holds Poll Next Month in Test of Modi’s Popularity

author: Alex Morales
description: The UK’s main opposition Conservative Party promised to slash spending on welfare, foreign aid and the civil service in a bid to re-establish its credentials as a sound steward of the economy 15 months after being ejected from power.
title: UK Conservatives Vow Trump-Like Cuts to Aid and Civil Service

author: William Horobin
description: Sebastien Lecornu unexpectedly resigned as France’s prime minister on Monday, blaming the intransigence of the groups in the country’s fractured parliament and deepening a national political crisis.
title: French Premier Quits After Macron’s Cabinet Gamble Backfires

author: Frank Jomo
description: Malawi’s president appointed a new finance minister and replaced his security chiefs after being sworn in at the weekend.
title: Malawi President Names Finance Minister, Replaces Security Heads

author: Enda Curran
description: When recent data showed the US economy grew by the fastest pace in nearly two years, the White House released a statement hailing the “Trump economy’s explosive growth,” which proved “so called ‘experts’” wrong.
title: Trump’s Contradiction: Demanding Steep Rate Cuts for a ‘Booming’ Economy

author: Souhail Karam
description: Moroccan activists urged the monarchy to directly start talks with a youth-led movement behind ongoing nationwide protests, sidelining the government and signaling broader support for demonstrations that erupted last month.
title: Moroccan Activists Urge Monarchy Talks as Protest Support Widens

author: Laura Curtis
description: President Donald Trump has warned of disaster if the Supreme Court overturns his signature tariffs. For starters, it would unleash a bureaucratic nightmare involving reams of refund paper checks.
title: If Trump’s Tariffs Are Ruled Illegal, Businesses Expect Refund Chaos

author: Fadwa Hodali
description: Years of broken promises have left deep scars and many wonder if this is merely a pause before the next storm.
title: Palestinian Skepticism Toward Trump’s Peace Plan Runs Deep

author: Sotiris Nikas, Paul Tugwell
description: Greece’s pile of borrowings are now estimated to have fallen to the lowest since 2009, before financial turmoil then forced the country to seek the first bailout of its decade-long crisis.
title: Greece Forecasts Debt Ratio for 2025 to Reach Pre-Bailout Low

author: Selcan Hacaoglu, Firat Kozok, Patrick Sykes
description: Turkey is discussing developing rare-earth reserves in western Anatolia with the US, marking a shift toward its NATO ally after similar talks with China and Russia slowed amid disagreements over technology transfer and refining rights.
title: Turkey Eyes US Rare Earths Deal After China, Russia Talks Slow

author: Greg Sullivan
description: Ukraine and Russia traded drone strikes overnight, continuing a pattern of targeting energy infrastructure that left thousands without electricity.
title: Ukraine and Russia Drone Strikes Leave Thousands Without Power

description: Sebastien Lecornu on Oct. 3. Photographer: Alain Jocard/Getty Images
title: Lecornu Blames Opposition Parties, Internal Dissention for Resignation

author: John Ainger
description: When Brazil was named host of the COP30 climate summit two years ago, it was seen as the perfect celebration of the 10th anniversary of the Paris Agreement, where nations pledged to keep climate change within safe limits.
title: Six Ways the COP30 Climate Summit Can Succeed or Fail

author: William Horobin
description: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu resigned Monday morning, just a day after President Emmanuel Macron named a new cabinet that was broadly criticized.
title: French Prime Minister Lecornu Has Resigned After Cabinet Panned

author: Dan Strumpf, Tooba Khan
description: Pakistan hailed the Chinese weapons systems it deployed during its four-day clash with India in May as performing “exceptionally well,” in the latest endorsement of the Beijing-made arms that comprise the bulk of Islamabad’s recent purchases.
title: Chinese Arms Did ‘Exceptionally’ Against India, Pakistan Says

author: Kentaro Tsutsumi, Yasutaka Tamura
description: Cash-rich companies in Japan may feel the heat after the election win of the pro-stimulus conservative Sanae Takaichi, as she has in the past expressed concerns about excess corporate cash holdings, according to some strategists.
title: Japan’s Cash-Rich Firms May Face Pressure after Takaichi Win

author: Andrea Dudik, Peter Laca, Daniel Hornak
description: Billionaire Andrej Babis set about forging a new Czech government hours after scoring his best-ever election victory, with his return to power poised to bolster the ascendant ranks of populist leaders in the European Union.
title: Czech Billionaire’s Comeback a Boon to Europe’s Populist Right

author: Craig Stirling, Zoe Schneeweiss
description: The Federal Reserve and global peers appear set to keep cutting interest rates in the remainder of this year, carrying on where much of Europe has left off.
title: Fed Set to Drive Global Rate Cuts as Europe Shifts to Pause

author: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers
description: The European Central Bank is heading into a two-year shake-up that will replace two-thirds of its top leadership — including President Christine Lagarde.
title: Race for ECB’s No. 2 Job to Shape Search for Lagarde Succession

author: Sakura Murakami
description: Sanae Takaichi, the newly elected leader of Japan’s ruling party, appears set to arrange key posts to address major challenges ahead, from shoring up party unity to curbing concerns over her fiscal stance.
title: Japan’s Takaichi Set to Tackle Ruling Party Unity With Key Posts

author: Erik Larson, Wendy Benjaminson
description: A federal judge in Portland, Oregon, blocked President Donald Trump from sending any federalized National Guard troops to the city during protests against his immigration crackdown, doubling down on a narrower order issued a day earlier.
title: Trump Blocked by Judge From Sending California Troops to Oregon

author: Shoko Oda
description: The woman expected to be Japan’s next prime minister is set to keep nuclear power at the core of the nation’s energy strategy, while reducing emphasis on readily available renewables like solar.
title: Japan’s Incoming Leader to Put Nuclear at Center of Energy Plan
